Introduction
Hi, my name is Matt Grayson and I'm the Editor of Steampunk Journal (www.steampunkjournal.org) which is currently the most popular online steampunk magazine in the World.
I grew up in Sheffield, UK and I took an interest in photography from an early age. In fact, I have over 20 years of experience. I can turn my hand to any type of photography, but my passion is portraiture.
My campaign is to raise funds to build a subscription based website by steampunks, for everyone interested in this amazing science fiction inspired by the 19th century aesthetic.

The Hellfire Club will feature galleries of photoshoots up to artistic nude level. They will have models of all genders in various situations that will always sport a steampunk or Victorian theme to them. Not being gender specific is something that hasn't been done before on a website like this and will reinforce the steampunk ethic of inclusivity. I will also look to take on shoots from steampunk photographers and steampunks from the community who wish to model.
Members will have to pay a monthly fee to access the site and all the shoots that are available to see in the gallery. Everyone involved in producing a shoot will get paid in some way.

By contributing to the success of The Hellfire Club, you will be expanding a business that is already on the rise. My magazine, Steampunk Journal, is the most popular steampunk magazine in the world. I already have campaigns in place to help the community, such as Steampunk Write, Steampunk Read. It's designed to give independent authors some exposure of their novel right into the faces of the people that they want to read it. I champion supporting independent artists and always look to help them as much as possible. With an arm of the business bringing in finances, I can maintain the Journal as a free resource for steampunks and even expand to some other projects I've had to shelve due to costs.
I'm looking to raise £13,000 in order to fund the bulk of the outlay to get the Hellfire Club started. In order to have something for people to subscribe to, the site needs to have shoots accessible from the time of launch. I wouldn't be happy paying a monthly subscription for an empty website, so I can't expect anyone else to. I predict that having 20 shoots to upload will be good number with ten online at launch. That gives a buffer of another 10 shoots should I run into delays or other problems.
The cost of a single shoot is broken down typically into the following sections*:
Model hire £135
Make-up artist £180
Studio: £45
Clothing hire £50
Props travel costs £35
Retouching £205
Total: £650
*prices are for half a day shooting (approx 4 hours)


Perks for investment
The amount that you decide to contribute will determine the perks that you get and I've thought long and hard about what to award the lovely people that help me. Based on an estimate of a monthly cost of around £12 a month to join the site when it's live, I decided to give some discount to Indiegogo investors. Therefore, for just £10 investment, you will get 1 month access to the site. This will increase by a month at £10 intervals and from Level Three of investment I'll start giving away images that will be of a scene from your favourite shoot. At Level Five, the pictures will be printed and signed by the photographer, making a unique artwork even more rare as these will only happen for investors of the initial launch!
As the levels of investment rise, the pictures will become albums and you'll even be invited to input your creative ideas into a shoot at the top tier investment level.
I've also included three special stages especially for businesses. These will range from sponsorship of shoots with 12 month access, to full creative control of the shoot, to including company branding in photographs and advertising on Steampunk Journal.
Should not all the funds be raised, I will use what I have to get as many shoots done as I can. I've not included myself in any totals as I will be financing part of the project myself and I don't think it would be proper. I'll also be funding and building the site myself while the shoots are taking place.
However, if the target gets smashed and we go over, I will be able to expand the benefits such as a custom made website for ultra smooth viewing and a book of images if we do really well. Anything we have spare will either go to more shoots or I'll get some little goodies made up to hand out to people who have helped in the campaign.

One of my aims for the site is to empower the people who pose for the camera. This won't be a seedy website with naked girls. The site will have a variation of clothing removal which will be completely at the request of the model. I want the Hellfire Club to do what burlesque has done whereby it gives people self confidence. That's why the people taking part will be all genders, skin tones and orientations. Any adult who wants to take part will be welcome to be in front of my camera.
Aside from the confidence boost that people can get, they'll also get paid a reasonable wage for working for the Hellfire Club. There's a great deal of angst at the moment surrounding artists and how they feel that people are taking advantage of them under the banner of "exposure".
Risks and overcoming objections

I'm a regular guy in a regular life, so obviously not everything will go right. Problems rose from the start before I even started planning the campaign. I contacted 30 people who I thought may be interested in working with me and I only received 5 replies. Eventually I managed to find more people and I have a good number of people looking forward to working with me. The biggest risk is people's reliability. However, people working on a shoot for money are much more likely to show up than those working for free. That's another reason I knew I had to raise the funds to pay them.
I expect to run into issues with the site build. I'll be using an entirely new system which is why I'll be starting from when shooting begins. That way I'll have a good 20-30 weeks to get it up and running. I ran into build issues with Steampunk Journal though but it's a smooth running, attractive and bright website now.
I'm a grafter, I currently work on a farm delivering goods and that can be up to 1.5 tonnes a day. I also look after my two children on my own and run the magazine when I'm not doing either of those things, so I'm not averse to hard work. I'm also more determined about this project than anything else I've done. I've even made a video! With me talking on it!
I've been taking pictures for over 20 years now and I know how the industry works, so I'll always have a back up plan. I also worked for a large magazine for two years, so I understand how to make the website popular in the ranks. That's why searching general steampunk terms brings Steampunk Journal either to the top of the list, or within the top three:

Steampunk news: 2 (after steampunknews.co.uk)
Steampunk reviews: 1
Steampunk articles: 1
Steampunk interviews: 1

This demostrates how seriously I take my work, how reputable I am and how focused I am to make my projects the best they can be.
What you can doI really hope by now you can see what an amazing website this could grow to be. I also hope that this is something that you want to invest in. Simply click the preferred box in the top right corner. I know what it's like to have little or no money, but still have the compassion to want to help with a project you believe in. Don't feel that if you can't spare any funds that you can't help. I need as many people as I can get to spread the word about the Hellfire Club. I need people who can see this is going to be a success to help me make it the success they desire it to be. I will still reward people who help in these ways, even if it's like a Bookmark or a CD or something. I will find a way to say thank you.So share this project, tell people about it, register your interest on the Steampunk Journal Landing page where I'll update by email. Liking and sharing posts extends the organic spread of posts on social media, so anything like that which can help with will be gratefully received. Please accept my advance thanks for reading about my project and I hope that I've convinced you that this is a wonderful investment opportunity. If you have any other questions, though, please feel free to get in touch.

story:
We live in the world of information and digital technologies. Both of them go hand in hand and probably no one can imagine living without them. But what happens if one of them skews the other one? What if information being presented is not as true as it looks like? 

Mounting someone face to another photo is pretty funny and shows us how impressive the tools are nowadays. Artificial intelligence can construct whole images from nothing and so it can construct faces on those images, too. How would you prove if it creates your face by chance that this is not a real footage?

Generally, how can you prove or verify digital photographs’ credibility?

Now you can capture photos with the ability to be verified! 

Let's create photos that can be trusted!

Motivation

We plan to provide a wide spectrum of users and businesses with tools to create credible photos and the services to effectively use these photos.
We focus on authors, owners, publishers, use rights, privacy, and security of digital photography.
And, of course, on the authenticity and quality of the image itself.

Please, read our story to get the key views of the service and values it can provide. 
You will also get the understanding of the perks and that is important for us, to be for you as clear as possible.

What is the Trusted image?

The Trusted image now is an iOS application for iPhones for secure photo capturing, verification and signature management from the users’ point of view. And at the same time, there is an online services part responsible for communicating with users through the application and for solving their requests like signing and verification of images.

One of the key building blocks of the Trusted image is the signature! As a part of an image, yet invisible to human eyes, it is still resistible against:

  • brightness manipulations
  • color manipulations
  • contrast manipulations
  • converting to grayscale
  • convolution filters
  • scale - the scale factor is variable and depends on image visual attributes
  • flipping and rotations - rotations in 90° steps CW or CCW

What the Trusted image service produces?

Our service produces digital photographs signed by our so-called "Image Adaptive Neural Networks". These networks work with the image data the way that they do not visually corrupt the image. We are targeting visual authenticity so the Trusted image application always captures at the highest resolution and uses lossless compression on captured photos. If the user decides to sign the photo, it is uploaded to our service. After the photo is signed, we inform the user that Trusted images are available to download. 

The service produce the "Trusted image Original" - full resolution, losslessly compressed TIFF file. As the name implies, this is the most valuable photo for the user! The key to the service features. From this photo, you can create custom or predefined signed derivates in the future.

At the same time, it offers the first "Trusted image Derivate" - full resolution, lossy compressed JPEG file as the first derivate of the original. This photo cannot be further derivated and signed using the service!

Note: Authors must download signed photos within a month from their signature. Once downloaded successfully to the Trusted image application, they are deleted on the service side.

! The service doesn't depend on stored visual data, so we do not store such data !
As there is no visual representation of your signed photo stored on our side, it is important to keep at least one Trusted image Original copy of your photo safe and ideally backed up for your future use! 

The verification and analysis part of the service produces Verification Reports. These reports show you what we know about the image being verified with respect to the users and image privacy settings. In deeper analysis (change detection for example), it provides reports showing what and where some image changes happened.

Who can or should use Trusted image and how?

This funny question has caused us multiple mental exhaustion, mass headaches, but also amazement at how it could basically be simple. 

Our principle is to give some benefits to parties involved in the digital photo lifetime. The main benefit is the photo itself, because it gets new properties with the signature, yet without losing quality. And photos are used almost everywhere. See below for some potential users.

Photographers

As a photographer of any level, you are probably facing many of "impractical" weaknesses of the digital photography. A lot of questions starting with "How..." For example: How do you prove the ownership of the photo? How do you prove the authenticity of the photo? How do you prove that you haven’t modified the photo? 

With Trusted image, you can set yourself free of these questions and just use them! You, as an author, will literally become entangled in the original photo you capture and sign. But don't worry, no one can see it, nor can we. Your image will be visually the same as without the signature! 

Media

Publish or not to publish? It is a basic question for you, isn't it? How do you check the photos at the inputs? You believe in your own photographers of course... But is it enough? Aren't there some more photos of a particular situation you are telling the world about? Do you have a budget big enough to handle all of your photographers happy? There can be a fleet of your photo sources around the world without you moving from your office desk!

With Trusted image, you can verify any signed photo, even from unknown sources to you, within a minute after the delivery! And you will see if it is authentic and trustworthy. We are also planning to upgrade in a way that you will be able to ask if you can use the photo or request permissions from the author. And there can be much more.

Photo stocks

Data duplication, authenticity, and uniqueness? Do you or your IT staff talk about them? And how about the authors? Aren't there copies of the same photo with different properties, modifications, or even authors? 

With Trusted image, you can quickly define the amount of trust you require, verify the images at the inputs and very effectively stay "clean" from duplicates as well as build and keep the trust between you and your customers or sources.

Insurance companies

Do you have a fleet of employees to document every case? How do they capture? Do they have access to these photos? Are the photos authentic? Do they document the situation on-site?

Wouldn't it be nice to have these photos from anyone around and be sure they are authentic, unmodified, thus usable to your business?

With Trusted image, you can use any verified photo you receive from anyone. You are able to check the date and time and the location of the photo and, of course, the authenticity.

The Public

We all read the web, news, social media... And there are photos just like everywhere. Are they authentic? Can or should you believe them as the reader and consumer? They can play big roles in everyone’s decision processes. But is it really an image of reality you are looking at? Isn't someone just trying to fool you?

With the Trusted image, the publishers, authors, companies, e-shops and others can be brave enough to support authentic photo content and express it by implementing upcoming features or integrations to prove their photo content is "fake-free".

What do you need to create or verify Trusted images?

It is simple. 

  • Trusted image for iPhone application (will be available free on Apple AppStore) - This allows you to capture photos, request their signature, download signed Ti Originals and Ti Derivates, verify images, manage the account, apply redeem codes (as of now) and more (as planned) like requesting "social networks" specific derivates, entitled derivates...
  • Trusted image account - Successfully registered and verified/activated account is the key to use the application and shoot photos with it. Shots are stored locally on your device until you decide to sign or not to sign the image. Once you decide not to sign the image, you will get the unsigned image, but you will lose the chance to sign this image.
  • Trusted image Crown(s) (TiCs) - These have the power to sign or verify images. Operations like signing or verifying are resources intensive tasks and they are accounted to users via TiCs. You must have some TiCs at your account to do such accounted operations.  

The Perks explained

Now you should have fresh information about what you need to use the Trusted image. Let's explain the Perks offered.

The Donate Perk is for you to support our ideas yet not planning to use the service.

As the Backer of Entry, Bronze, Silver or Gold Perk (and only in this case), you will get:

  • An active account for the time defined in particular Perk
  • Early access to Premium services and tools for the same time
  • Discounts on TiCs offers

The time periods will start counting at the launch time of the service for backers.

We will start offering our services only for Backers!

The Enterprise Perk is a bit different from the others. We offer one year of dedicated resources with the amount of 10.000 TiCs with up to 100 user accounts linked, plus our team capacities to discuss integration patterns possible to support backers systems and processes. 

Don't miss this chance to get an early access!

 

What will funds be used for?

The very basic idea of our service, to build the trust between the parties involved around images, might seem simple, but designing, developing and running all pieces of the system around this idea is unfortunately not of this kind.

We can split this topic into the following parts:

  • Operational expenses
    As we do computationally demanding tasks, we need to run on adequate hardware to be able to reach useful quality of services and as fast as possible. We do not want you to wait days for your signed photos! Our calculations and test show us that we can sign hundreds of thousands photos per month and verify more than a million of them. That is just an initial setup and sizing we need to start with. Our systems are ready to grow. But the computers and software cannot take care about themselves, so their running also involves some human resources.
  • Enhancements of the existing Trusted image parts (capacities)
    As we are finishing works on the Service and the Trusted image iOS application to be ready shortly after the campaign, we all know that nothing is perfect. There are places where we need or want to push a bit more on the development and enhance or fine tune existing functionalities. This applies to the systems of the Service as well as to the Trusted image iOS application. There are still works to be done to get things ready for a wide production use.
  • The Future
    For us to leverage more of the potential of the service, like advancing to other devices for capturing images, we are planning new features for users as well as for businesses. The funds can be used here too to start selected features development and this, again, needs capacities in a form of not only human resources of different kinds.

    And what the "upcoming features list" contains? A few unsorted examples:
    • Browser plugin for public verifications
    • JavaScript library for web integrated public fast verifications
    • Desktop management & signing application (Mac, Win, ...?)
    • Entitlements - You will be able to designate images for a concrete use on concrete webs, for example.
    • Rights support - Authors are undetachable from our photos, that is clear, but the ownership of different forms of use rights or full ownership of the photo can (and as to be able to) change in time. We are planning to provide these features so the Trusted image will never be "lost" in time. It can and it will have its lifetime documented.
    • Still cameras & other photo capture devices - We are sure there are ways to spread the Trusted image to other devices. Raised funds will help us explore the possibilities towards these devices.

We do not see the Trusted image as a small service in the future, so the goal is set as it is. We know it might look a bit high, but taking into account thousands of users and maybe millions of photos, and we also know we cannot do it effectively with four team members, you will probably find out that our goal is not that big in this context.

Reaching our goal can help us a lot to provide easy adoptable services quickly.

The team behind

We started this project two years ago with a minimal amount of people to be called a team - that is two. Designing the systems, solving daily challenges from technical to ethical fields, designing and tuning our neural networks up and down, back and forth. During the time we have enriched our team with two new members, so we have doubled the team. We have done a lot of work, but there is still work to be done. 

Robert Jarušek

Petr Soukup

Pavel Veškrna

Nikoleta Niklová

 

Do you like our ideas?

Whether you plan to become our backer or you just like our ideas, please, share our project with your friends and business partners to let them know that we are here!

THANK YOU

For more information about how it all happened or if you are interested in more technical background, please visit www.trusted-image.com/story

story:
"Imagine a large, circular cage. Inside this cage is a huge bear. The term 'bear's cage' is used to describe the precipitation that wraps around a mesocyclone. Within the mesocyclone a tornado can occur. The cage is the curtain of heavy precipitation that wraps around the rotating updraft. If a bear is present, it will be a tornado. When a storm chaser goes into the bear's cage, they risk being attacked by the tornado." - Meteorologist Jeff Haby

The Project

Hi!  I'm Conor Clancy; I'm a photographer and writer based in Philadelphia, PA and I launched Behind The Bear's Cage in May 2016 photographing a group of Oklahoma City-based storm chasers named Tornado Titans.  My initial goal was to bring viewers, quite literally, behind the bear's cage--an "all access" look at the rarely-documented life of a storm chaser.  You can check out the photos from that first visit here:

After nearly a year of reflection, research, and a bit of storm chasing on my own, I've become better acquainted with further aspects of the storm chasing community previously unknown to the general public.  Behind The Bear's Cage has grown, and I need your help to make it a reality.  In 2017, I plan to explore:

  • How storm chasers are using their hobby for the greater good; be it warning citizens via social media, educating the public on severe weather safety, to raising funds for disaster-stricken towns in the United States.
  • What motivates a human to chase a storm, and how chasing storms relates to their everyday life.
  • The competitive weather news market exclusive to Tornado Alley, and how citizens of the Great Plains deal with a constant tornado threat. 
  • Technology and social media, and how both entities have changed the way the public is notified of incoming severe weather.
  • How climate change is affecting the severity and frequency of tornado outbreaks.

Why are these issues important?  Most storm chasers are great people, doing what they are passionate about, on their own time.  A select few bad apples have given chasers a bad rap in recent years.  My goal with this year's iteration is to bring better visibility to the community's positive contributions; to foster a better relationship between local officials and storm chasers, while simultaneously illustrating the dangers of storm chasing with no experience.  A few bad apples shouldn't spoil the bunch.

How Will Your Contribution Help?

While last year's trip to Tornado Alley was incredibly successful, it landed me in extreme debt.  As Behind The Bear's Cage has become more dynamic, I'm no longer able to fund it myself.  This is where you guys come in!  Not a mile will be driven, no photograph made, nor will a single story be told without your support.

In order to truly immerse myself in the storm culture of the Great Plains, I've decided to spend the entirety of the second half of tornado season in Oklahoma City.  This will grant me the freedom to create, while getting a feel for the way of life in the Plains.  The funds raised through this campaign will go directly toward my living and travel expenses for that duration.  How much raise together directly correlates to length of my trip.  The longer I'm able to stay, the greater story we can tell:  $4,000 is the amount I would need to stay in the Plains from April 17 - May 31, which includes:  

  • Fuel costs, especially between Pennsylvania & Oklahoma.  
  • Shelter.  In the interest of keeping costs low, I will be "lodging" in home shares as opposed to hotel rooms.  Having access to a kitchen space will allow me to make my own food, which will also lower my total overhead costs.
  • When dealing with the weather, it is very important to have an emergency fund set aside.  The Emergencies portion is reserved to cover:
    • Should I need to cover a night of lodging after traveling a far distance from my base in Oklahoma City (this is most likely to happen while shadowing a storm chaser).
    • Should I encounter car trouble on my journey.

No fund raised will be spent extravagantly; I own all of my camera gear, and will not be renting anything.  I've designed a number of perks for backers... including one in which I will personally thank you from the front lines of a storm chase.

This project is not possible without you.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Follow Behind The Bear's Cage on social media!
    • Twitter: @BTBearsCage
    • Facebook: /behindthebearscage
    • Instagram: @behindthebearscage
  • Share our campaign on your own social media account!
story_txt:
"Imagine a large, circular cage. Inside this cage is a huge bear. The term 'bear's cage' is used to describe the precipitation that wraps around a mesocyclone. Within the mesocyclone a tornado can occur. The cage is the curtain of heavy precipitation that wraps around the rotating updraft. If a bear is present, it will be a tornado. When a storm chaser goes into the bear's cage, they risk being attacked by the tornado." - Meteorologist Jeff Haby
The Project

Fuel costs, especially between Pennsylvania & Oklahoma.  
Shelter.  In the interest of keeping costs low, I will be "lodging" in home shares as opposed to hotel rooms.  Having access to a kitchen space will allow me to make my own food, which will also lower my total overhead costs.
When dealing with the weather, it is very important to have an emergency fund set aside.  The Emergencies portion is reserved to cover:
Should I need to cover a night of lodging after traveling a far distance from my base in Oklahoma City (this is most likely to happen while shadowing a storm chaser).
Should I encounter car trouble on my journey.



No fund raised will be spent extravagantly; I own all of my camera gear, and will not be renting anything.  I've designed a number of perks for backers... including one in which I will personally thank you from the front lines of a storm chase.
This project is not possible without you.

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow Behind The Bear's Cage on social media!

Twitter: @BTBearsCage


Facebook: /behindthebearscage


Instagram: @behindthebearscage



Share our campaign on your own social media account!

story:
THE PROJECT

This photographic project stems from the need to report the relentless depopulation of the historic centre of Venice. 

Indeed, one of the dramas of this beautiful city is the loss of all the people who have lived in it since childhood through play, silence and first loves. Because a city that turns its back on those who remember it, which refuses to live through the love of those born there, is a city that has lost its way.

I thought about all this for a long time, because, as a citizen, I have experienced first-hand the sense of loneliness and regret that derive from seeing one's lifelong friends gradually leaving. So, I reflected on how to represent this departure and I realised that perhaps the most universal way was to contact my former classmates, meet with them and portray them, one by one.

Only 30% of them still live in the city.

THE PURPOSE

The purpose of this photographic project is to make  people aware of this problem which is particularly vivid in a city where, in the face of a constant decline in its number of inhabitants (and subsequent decline in services related to this), there is a continuous and constantly growing flow of tourists.

The short-term aim is to create a photographic exhibition with the material collected and the images created for the purpose of publishing the project and informing people.

In the future, the idea is to involve more and more subjects and create a photographic book that traces the memories of those who were born and lived in Venice.

THE AUTHOR

Barbara Zanon, born in 1979, Venetian.

Professional photographer since 2004, she has published in major national and international magazines (including Vogue, Elle, Vanity Fair, Forbes ,Time, EL Mundo, El Pais, Spiegel, Express, Stern, Financial Times, CNN, Life ecc) and has also worked with the most important photographic agencies, including Getty Images. She has exhibited in solo and group shows in NYC, Los Angeles, Barcelona, Budapest, Paris, London and Venice. 

She has won numerous international photographic competitions including: Gran Prix de Paris,  Lucie Awards, Renaissance Awards, Budapest Photo Award, Mifa, Julia Margaret Cameron Award. 

personal web site:  www.barbarazanon.com

story:
Hi everyone , I,m Cathy

I m a mum of 5, 2 daughters, a son and 2 step sons. They are all of an age now where they are starting to work on making their own future. My eldest son Barry is going to Queens University in September to study further on Computer Science after completing his foundation Degree with a regional college. I am a very proud mother. I studied myself to receive 9 Gcse's and a NVQ in Business Administration, but I finished education as I had my children young. I brought my children up myself and went through difficulties with health along the way.  I suffered badly with Post Natal Depression and was diagnosed later on in my 30's with Borderline Personality Disorder. I also suffer from Fibromyalgia, Arthritis in my back and hips and a few other different things. It became very difficult for me in life and I couldnt control the Borderline Personality. I tried to find a hobby for therapeutic reasons and eventually I found Photography. I loved it so much that I took myself back to College to study GCSE and passed. I then decided to go further and study at HND level and have completed this year with 4 Distinctions.  One dream that I have consistently had my whole life was to run my own business. Now I feel completely ready!! I started a page on Facebook after I completed my GCSE , so I could gain experience and get models as none of my family really liked to model (except 1 of my daughters). My page has grown to over 1000 likes. I have started going to an Understanding Enterprises course with CIDO Innovation centre and from here on I will have one to one mentoring and I am making up a business plan on the Go For It Programme. I want to open a Studio where I can run a business from. This would need a lot of funding and being on benefits I would find this so hard to do. I have studied hard regardless and don't ever intend to give in to any disabilities that I have.  I need to get premises, premises fitted out and more equipment. I have a lot already as I needed things to progress my studies. If I had funding and this came about I would do Photography sessions and I want to teach Photography and Photoshop, maybe even basic computers. There are so many people who would benefit. I would also like to sell my own framed prints. 

I would also like to give back to my community in the mental health . I have already experienced doing this and the results was very overwhelming. I want to help young people, mid age and older and have different projects in mind as to how I can achieve this. This is a cause that means so much to me and I love helping someone and making them smile. Its also important to me that people realise how worthy they are of life and helping them do better. I have been at very low points in my life and completely understand how it can be. With your help I can achieve something massive and of great worth to a whole community. I bet so many of you have known someone in life that have had mental health problems! Dementia is also a cause I would love to help and have an idea for this. 

I would need to raise £5000 + to enable this project as I have to think of start up costs, premises, fitting out and then soon as this happens, you need to think about equipment, insurances and lots of bills , so there really is a lot to getting started up. Your support on this journey would really be amazing and there are no words I can say that would express my gratitude. 

I am hoping to start some rewards for pledges that are made and I can do this in the form of discounted photography for you and your family to enjoy. I don't have a lot I can give in the form of items but your help , well you have no idea what it means to me.

I have a lot of extensions to add to my business plans as ways that I can overcome any hurdles which may arise and will add them when I have it all finalised. Thank you for taking the time to read this. Please share and help me get backing for this project, it all means the world!!!

story:
Be a part of a beautiful and awe-inspiring project

My name is Gianluigi Nicolosi and I am from sunny South Africa. I have a Bachelors degree in psychology and have been working adventure and wildlife camps before I came through to China to teach English. I am fluent in English and Italian and intermediate in Zulu, with beginner Mandarin and French. I have traveled Europe extensively as well as southern Africa and China.
I took up photography a few years back just as an interest, as a few friends of mine and relatives are avid photographers. I picked up the camera and just started playing around until i figured out what I was dong exactly (with the help of others when needed). One thing I found that fascinates me, in psychology and in aesthetics, is the face of people. In psychology the face is a gate way to the soul and thoughts of people, as behaviour is shown in the face; whether you know it or not. This is a universal trait that I am trying to capture of people. Thus, from the photos taken in Africa, and Europe and China, I would like to continue my collection so that once I have finished taking pictures around the world, I can show the world the diversity as well as similarities among all people. I believe this can further decrease the gaps between peoples perception of cultures and races. And besides, who doesn't like looking at a beautiful face. As a side note, i also take stunning landscape photographs as well as in action photos of people living their daily life...so be ready to be amazed.
At the moment, I have the funds for a plane ticket to the USA, but as far as spending money goes, I am running dry. I plan to go to the US at the end of September for 3 weeks to catalogue as much as I can in the time I have off from work. I am looking for a donation to help me reach my goal of 1000USD before i head off. This money will go towards my food accommodation and local transport expenses during the three week period.
I have thought abut some of the challenges facing me and have come up with some solutions to those problems. As i have stated before, i have traveled extensively and I am well prepared for any challenges or risks ahead. 
So don't be scared, help me get to the other side of the world to continue my catalogue, and you will get personalized photos sent straight to you to do as wish with them. If you fund, you can also request a specific photo that i may be able to shoot for you.
Thanks for you support guys...you all rock!!

story:
Update 3/9/16

I have raised $2180 with a few cash donations not added into this campaign.

Who I am, what I have done, and my character 

My name is Rich Wexler and I have been many things in this life. I have been a music promoter, an artist, photographer, filmmaker, a teacher (of workshops and certified in elementary and special ed), and more. I live my life like my heroes of the 1970's. For me this means being community-minded and trying to give back to my community. For every dollar I have ever earned, I try to give back to help someone else out, or to help underserved communities. I ran a music promotion organization called Sherman Arts (http://citypaper.net/articles/2005-09-08/music.... which created community and supported musicians financially as well as by providing promotion, advice, management, and press. I started this as a reaction to an artist friend who died because she fell ill and was uninsured. She could not get the full medical attention that she needed and she died. Sherman Arts put on many benefit concerts to raise funds for those without insurance so that they could get the support they needed. We were able to pay out about $10,000 over the years for these purposes. That work eventually led me to create an educational theater company for underserved communities.  We put on "Rent (http://citypaper.net/No-Other-Way)  in 2011, and "Avenue Q (http://www.newsworks.org/index.php/local/entert... in 2013 with a diverse cast of multicultural and LGBT teens. These projects were free for all participants. I also hosted a free storytelling class with the live storytelling podcast "Risk!" as a sponsor in 2015 as well as a free comic book arts class for teens and adults. 

Currently I am embarking on a new photography business that incorporates the same social service aspects of my previous work.


What this campaign is all about:
1. FUNDING MY ART SHOW - WHAT THAT MEANS TO ME
This campaign is about a few things. The first is to support my art show at The James Oliver Gallery starting April 9th through May 14th (http://www.jamesolivergallery.com) This show will feature 3D film images in the form of View-Master reels, the thin cardboard disks that contain matching film images viewable through a special viewer, images I've captured on a stereoscopic camera which is basically the home version of the View-Master technology we all grew up with. There will be about 50 or more View-Master viewers and about 100 discs on hand (reels of original work) and I will also be able to project stereoscopic images on the wall. The show will also feature about 200 polaroids, a sample of some digital 3D work I've done (viewable on a 3D television), as well as some super-8 work that I've done. While the show will primarily focus on work that I've captured, I will also feature found work that I've curated; polaroids, View-Master reels and the like. It is very expensive to stage an art show and other than through this campaign, I am funding everything myself. This is a very well known gallery in Philadelphia and even getting this opportunity is huge for me. This will get me much needed attention as an artist that will help me further the business I am basing around these activities. I am also hoping to sell my work, an important step towards making this effort sustainable.

2 CREATING  MY WORK - WHY IT IS IMPORTANT

My main focus in my work at this point is shooting on film with the personal View-Master camera, a stereoscopic camera created in 1955 for home use - to create personal View-Master reels.The reason I shoot in 3D with film is because I can honestly say there is no experience quite like looking at these images on a 3D viewer. The crux of the technology is that two separate photos are taken of a single subject and then recombined while viewing to produce a binocular depth simulation- a simple 3D effect. It is the only way to get an image that is this close to what it looks like in the real world. The result is a clear backlit image that has the most depth I have ever seen in a 3D medium. I can tell you that people are blown away from my work. It's something they fall in love with at first glance. Polaroids have a similar effect as well. They age as time goes by, kind of like a good wine. When you look at them and hold them it has the energy of the person and the time that they were alive, whenever the image was captured. I want to help people document the important events of their lives, their families' lives, their pets' lives, and their friends' lives.

3. USING THIS TECHNOLOGY TO HELP UNDESERVED COMMUNITIES
I want to provide photography workshops for underserved communities to tell their stories as well as help artists with free and discounted promotional pictures; furthermore I want to be available to document emerging events and worthwhile causes as they crop up. I have the track record that shows my commitment to such work. You can be assured that any success I have will be bounced back into projects like these.

WHAT I AM PROMISING

a) I promise to spend all funds raised by this campaign on the budget listed below, a wishlist of photography supplies and services.

b) I will exhibit at the James Oliver Gallery opening April 9th, featuring the work described above and filled out by work made possible by your contributions. I will build my business from there.

c) I will honor all perks.

 

Budget and usage of Funds 

This is the list of durable gear and consumable media and services that I hope to purchase from the proceeds of the campaign:

$345  30 rolls of Fujifilm Fujichrome Provia 100F Color slide film - $11.50 per roll. This makes approximately 900 images (100 discs) 

$375  125 Impossible Film Polaroids 

$300 125 Viewmaster Empty Reels (the reels the images get put into)

$500 2  3D Viewmaster Cameras 

$360 Processing for 30 rolls of film

$400 Basic Photography Lighting 

$300 A spare cutter to cut the slides 

$170 Impossible Film Instant Lab - makes it possible to make Polaroids from photos on iPhones and such.

$400 To hire an assistant at $20 an hour for 20 hours.

$100 Travel expenses 

The more successful this campaign, the more film stock I can buy, the more can be processed and the more ancillary gear I can use to complete these tasks and operate in a manner that helps many people. 

WHAT YOU GIVE IS WHAT YOU GET

What I offer in return are many amazing perks. I am offering event photography, portraits, my work for your collection and much more. Plus the knowledge that you know I will be working for many important causes. 

Risks & Challenges

I may face many obstacles in this process. In the past projects that I worked on I have never quit and I have worked as hard as I needed to make things work, even if it meant I made very little money. When I set my mind to something - I make it work. In the last musical project I worked on, I was able to raise $12,000 to pull it off, as well as change the lives of the teens I worked with. Nothing will stop me from keeping my core promises to you.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot afford to give, I am going to need a ton of help spreading the word on this project. I will need to reach out to a few thousand people. If everyone shares this with their network of people, I can achieve that. I am hoping to get approximately $25-50 dollars from 200 people. I know I can do that with your help and support.

Sherman Arts put on many benefit concerts to raise funds for those without insurance so that they could get the support they needed. We were able to pay out about $10,000 over the years for these purposes. That work eventually led me to create an educational theater company for underserved communities.  We put on "Rent (http://citypaper.net/No-Other-Way)  in 2011, and "Avenue Q (http://www.newsworks.org/index.php/local/entert... in 2013 with a diverse cast of multicultural and LGBT teens. These projects were free for all participants. I also hosted a free storytelling class with the live storytelling podcast "Risk!" as a sponsor in 2015 as well as a free comic book arts class for teens and adults. 



Currently I am
embarking on a new photography business that incorporates the same social service aspects of my previous work.
What this campaign is all about:
1. FUNDING MY ART SHOW - WHAT THAT MEANS TO ME
This campaign is about a few things. The first is to support my art show at The James Oliver Gallery starting April 9th through May 14th (http://www.jamesolivergallery.com) This show will feature 3D film images in the form of View-Master reels, the thin cardboard disks that contain matching film images viewable through a special viewer, images I've captured on a stereoscopic camera which is basically the home version of the View-Master technology we all grew up with. There will be about 50 or more View-Master viewers and about 100 discs on hand (reels of original work) and I will also be able to project stereoscopic images on the wall. The show will also feature about 200 polaroids, a sample of some digital 3D work I've done (viewable on a 3D television), as well as some super-8 work that I've done. While the show will primarily focus on work that I've captured, I will also feature found work that I've curated; polaroids, View-Master reels and the like. It is very expensive to stage an art show and other than through this campaign, I am funding everything myself. This is a very well known gallery in Philadelphia and even getting this opportunity is huge for me. This will get me much needed attention as an artist that will help me further the business I am basing around these activities. I am also hoping to sell my work, an important step towards making this effort sustainable.2 CREATING  MY WORK - WHY IT IS IMPORTANTMy main focus in my work at this point is shooting on film with the personal View-Master camera, a stereoscopic camera created in 1955 for home use - to create personal View-Master reels.The reason I shoot in 3D with film is because I can honestly say there is no experience quite like looking at these images on a 3D viewer. 
The crux of the technology is that two separate photos are taken of a
single subject and then recombined while viewing to produce a binocular depth
simulation- a simple 3D effect. It is the only way to get an image that is this close to what it looks like in the real world. The result is a clear backlit image that has the most depth I have ever
seen in a 3D medium. I can tell you that people are blown away from my work. It's something they fall in love with at first glance. Polaroids have a similar effect as well. They age as time goes by, kind of like a good wine. When you look at them and hold them it has the energy of the person and the time that they were alive, whenever the image was captured. I want to help people document the important events of their lives, their families' lives, their pets' lives, and their friends' lives. 3. USING THIS TECHNOLOGY TO HELP UNDESERVED COMMUNITIES
I want to provide photography workshops for underserved communities to tell their stories as well as help artists with free and discounted promotional pictures; furthermore I want to be available to document emerging events and worthwhile causes as they crop up. I have the track record that shows my commitment to such work. You can be assured that any success I have will be bounced back into projects like these.
WHAT I AM PROMISING 
a) I promise to spend all funds raised by this campaign on the budget listed below, a wishlist of photography supplies and services.
b) I will exhibit at the James Oliver Gallery opening April 9th, featuring the work described above and filled out by work made possible by your contributions. I will build my business from there.
c) I will honor all perks.
 

Budget and usage of
Funds 
This is the list of
durable gear and consumable media and services that I hope to purchase from the proceeds of
the campaign: 
$345  30
rolls of Fujifilm Fujichrome Provia 100F Color slide film - $11.50 per roll. This makes
approximately 900 images (100 discs) 
$375  125 Impossible Film Polaroids 
$300 125
Viewmaster Empty Reels (the reels the images get put into)
$500 2  3D Viewmaster
Cameras 
$360 Processing for 30 rolls of film
$400 Basic Photography
Lighting 
$300 A spare cutter to
cut the slides 
$170 Impossible Film
Instant Lab - makes it possible to make Polaroids from photos on iPhones and
such.
$400 To hire an
assistant at $20 an hour for 20 hours.
$100 Travel
expenses 
The more successful this campaign, the more film stock I can buy,
the more can be processed and the more ancillary gear I can use to complete
these tasks and operate in a manner that helps many people. 
WHAT YOU GIVE IS WHAT YOU GET
What I offer in return
are many amazing perks. I am offering event photography, portraits, my work for
your collection and much more. Plus the knowledge that you know I will be
working for many important causes. 
Risks & Challenges
I may face many
obstacles in this process. In the past projects that I worked on I have never quit
and I have worked as hard as I needed to make things work, even if it meant I
made very little money. When I set my mind to something - I make it work. In the
last musical project I worked on, I was able to raise $12,000 to pull it off,
as well as change the lives of the teens I worked with. Nothing will stop me from keeping my core promises to you.
Other Ways You Can
Help
If you cannot afford
to give, I am going to need a ton of help spreading the word on this project. I
will need to reach out to a few thousand people. If everyone shares this with
their network of people, I can achieve that. I am hoping to get approximately
$25-50 dollars from 200 people. I know I can do that with your help and
support.

story:
Resumen/Summary

Somos Misha Vallejo e Isadora Romero, fotógrafos ecuatorianos. Nos mueven las historias que se relacionan con nuestro entorno, las que nos permiten ampliar horizontes y relacionarnos con las personas.

We are Misha Vallejo and Isadora Romero, Ecuadorian photographers. We are moved by stories that relate to our environment, the ones that allow us to broaden our horizons and get in touch with people.

Puño y Letra  es un trabajo que venimos realizando con mucho cariño desde abril del año pasado a raíz del terremoto de 7.8 grados en la escala de Richter que afectó gran parte de la costa ecuatoriana. Es un trabajo colaborativo que reúne fotografías instantáneas y testimonios escritos a mano por los afectados. Y ahora queremos convertirlo en un libro. Nuestra motivación es generar un documento inclusivo profundo, donde las voces de los afectados sean el principal recurso narrativo.  Tu ayuda permitirá que estos testimonios no sean olvidados. Nosotros estamos convencidos que deben ser recordados como parte de la historia.

Handwritten is a body of work that we have been doing with a lot of care since April 2016 following the earthquake of 7.8 degrees in the Richter Scale that affected a big part of the Ecuadorian coast. This is a collaborative work that gathers instant photographs and handwritten testimonies of the survivors. Now we want to make it into a book. We are motivated to create an inclusive and profound document where the voices of the affected people will be the main narrative resource. Your help will allow these testimonies not to be forgotten. We are convinced that these should be a part of history.

Sobre el Libro / About the book

Una semana después del terremoto en Ecuador, comenzamos este proyecto que consistió en fotografiar a los damnificados con cámaras Polaroid de revelado instantáneo. Partiendo de la premisa de la emergencia psicológica, realizamos las fotografías durante un proceso de atenta escucha y contención empática. Luego, les solicitamos a los retratados describir sus sentimientos, pensamientos o reflexiones y escribirlos sobre las fotografías; también fotografiamos objetos valiosos que ellos lograron sacar de sus hogares. Las fotografías fueron realizadas en las ciudades y pueblos más afectados de las provincias de Manabí y Esmeraldas.

One week after the earthquake in Ecuador, we began the production of the project Handwritten. It consisted in portraying the victims using instant Polaroid cameras. Based on the premise of psychological emergency, we made the photographs during a process of attentive listening and empathic restraint. Later we asked the subjects to describe their feelings, thoughts or reflections and write them on the photographs. Also, valuable objects that they managed to rescue from their homes were photographed. The pictures were made in the most affected cities and villages of Manabí and Esmealdas provinces.

Puño y Letra es un ensayo sobre la memoria, un análisis sobre qué significa la imagen en momentos de catástrofe. Las fotografías Polaroid por su característica de soporte efímero, crean una analogía con la fragilidad de la memoria humana. Este proyecto tiene más de 80 testimonios de resiliencia. Sabemos que es un importante documento de memoria colectiva y por eso queremos preservarlo en un libro.

Handwritten is an essay about memory, an analysis of what do images mean in catastrophic times. Due to its characteristics as an ephemeral support, the Polaroid pictures create the analogy to human memory. The photographic project gathers more than 80 testimonies of resilience. We know this is an important document of collective memory and this is why we want to preserve it in book form.

Entre otros, Puño y Letra ganó el Premio Fotoperiodismo por la Paz Juan Antonio Serrano de Ecuador que consta de una beca de producción artística. Ésta será utilizada en su totalidad para financiar una parte de los costos de la publicación. El resto lo realizaremos con ayuda de colaboradores como tú.

El libro será un objeto de altísima calidad editado por Claudi Carreras, reconocido curador y editor iberoamericano. Los fondos recaudados se destinarán a la edición, diseño, diagramación, pruebas de color, impresión y distribución del libro. Imprimiremos un tiraje de 1000 ejemplares y un porcentaje importante será distribuido a centros educativos, de investigación y bibliotecas del Ecuador. Además, queremos entregar el libro a todas las familias que compartieron sus testimonios con nosotros.

Among other, Handwritten won the Photojournalism for Peace Prize of Ecuador, which consists of a production grant that will be used in its entirety to cover part of the costs of the publication. The rest will be done with the help of contributors like you.

The book will be a high quality object that will be edited by the recognized Spanish editor and curator Claudi Carreras. The gathered funds will be used to edit, design, make color proofs, print and distribute the book. 1000 copies will be printed and a percentage of them will be distributed to educational and research centers. We also want to give a copy of the book to all the families and people that shared their testimonies with us.

Características aproximadas del libro:

Pasta dura

25 cm x 18 cm

108 páginas

Páginas con laminado UV selectivo

Edición de 1000 ejemplares

Approximate characteristics of the book:

Hardcover

25 cm x 18 cm

108 pages

Pages with selective UV coating

Edition of 1000

Al momento de lanzar esta campaña se ha cumplido un año y medio del terremoto. Si bien hay varios proyectos de reconstrucción en la zona afectada, aún hay mucho por hacer. Es por esto que hemos decidido aliarnos con la organización Actuemos Ecuador. El 30% de las ganancias de la venta del libro se destinará a proyectos de reconstrucción antisísmica que esta organización tiene en diferentes zonas afectadas. Visita su página para conocer más sobre ellos.

At the present time, it has already passed a year and a half since the earthquake. While there are several actions that are taking place to solve the problems of the affected area, there is still a lot to do. This is why we decided to ally us to the Actuemos Ecuador Organization. 30% of the proceeds from the sale of the book will go to the maintenance of the projects that Actuemos Ecuador has in several affected regions. Feel free to visit their page to know more about them.

 

Retos y riesgos / Risks and challenges

Nuestro sueño es que el libro esté listo para la conmemoración de los dos años del terremoto, es decir en abril de 2018. Para nosotros, esta campaña es una manera de vender el libro por adelantado porque gracias al apoyo de las organizaciones aliadas podemos asegurar su realización. En caso de no completar la meta de esta campaña, el libro tardará más tiempo en salir.

Our dream is the book to be ready for the two-year earthquake anniversary in April 2018. For us, this campaign is a way to sell the books beforehand because thanks to the support of allied organizations we can guarantee its realization. In case we don’t reach our goal, the book will take longer to be ready.

Recompensas / Rewards:

Sabemos que los costos de envío a veces son un inconveniente, por eso podemos enviar cualquiera de las recompensas con amigos o gente conocida de confianza que se mueven entre Ecuador, América y Europa. Para esto cuando elijas la recompensa elige la opción de envío en Ecuador y al término de la campaña nos pondremos en contacto contigo para coordinar el envío amigo.

We know that delivery costs can be an inconvenient sometimes. This is why we can send you any rewards with friends that travel between Ecuador, The Americas and Europe. For this, after you select your reward, choose it to be delivered to Ecuador and at the end of the crowd funding campaign we will get in touch with you to coordinate this friendly shipping.

Aparte del libro, en esta campaña tenemos varias recompensas que pueden ser tuyas por tu colaboración:

Besides the book, for this campaign we have several rewards that will be yours in exchange of your collaboration:

REPRODUCCIÓN POLAROID / POLAROID REPRODUCTION

Una reproducción en papel fotográfico de las fotografías polaroid. Puedes seleccionar la que prefieras cuando nos contactemos para la entrega.

A reproduction of the original Polaroid photographs printed on photographic paper. You can select the one you like when we will contact you for the delivery.

 

WAKA

La primera edición de la revista de fotografía Waka del colectivo Runa Photos. Es una publicación independiente que contiene imágenes de la serie ImproVISION 52 realizadas por Karla Gachet, Ivan Kashinsky y Misha Vallejo.

The first issue of the Waka Magazine produced by the Runa Photos collective. This is an independent publication that gathers images of the ImproVISION 52 series done by Karla Gachet, Ivan Kashinsky and Misha Vallejo.

 

INSTAPRINTS

Fotografías de 40 x40 cm impresas en papel de algodón y firmadas por Misha o Isadora. Cada fotografía está seriada (se imprimirán máximo 7 copias de cada una) y puedes seleccionar la que prefieras cuando nos contactemos para la entrega.

40 x 40 cm sized photographs printed on cotton paper, signed by Misha or Isadora. Each photograph is part of a series of maximum 7 copies. You can select the one you like when we will contact you for the delivery.

Sobre los autores / About the authors

Misha Vallejo. Ecuador, 1985
Es un fotógrafo que se mueve en la frontera entre lo documental y artístico.  En el 2014 terminó una Maestría en Artes en Fotografía Documental en la Universidad de las Artes de Londres. Es miembro del colectivo Runa Photos desde el 2012. En el 2016 publica su primer fotolibro “Al otro lado” con Editora Madalena de Sao Paulo, Brasil. Esta publicación fue seleccionada como uno de los mejores libros de autor del año por el festival Rencontres de la Photographie de Arles, Francia, obtuvo una mención de honor en el Premio Internacional Felifa-Fola Argentina 2016, fue elegido mejor libro de fotografía del 2016 de Brasil, fue incluido en la exhibición Fenómeno Fotolibro en el CCCB de Barcelona y fue incluido en la exhibición de fotolibros de Athens Photo Festival 2017.
Su trabajo ha sido mostrado en varios festivales y exposiciones colectivas de Latinoamérica, Europa y Asia, además de haber sido expuesto en solitario en Rusia y Ecuador. Entre sus reconocimientos más importantes se encuentran haber ganado el Premio Fotoperiodismo Por La Paz (2017), el Premio Nacional de las Artes de Ecuador Nuevo Mariano Aguilera (2015), haber tenido menciones de honor en el concurso FotoVisura (2015, 2013 y 2011) y haber sido finalista en el concurso Sony World Photography Awards (2015).

Misha Vallejo. Ecuador, 1985.

He is a photographer that moves between documentary and art photography. In 2014 he finished an MA in Documentary Photography at the University of the Arts London. He is a member of the Runa Photos collective since 2012. In 2016 he published his first photobook “Al otro lado” with Brazilian publishing house Editora Madalena. This publication was selected as one of the best author books by the Rencontres de la Photographie Festival in Arles (France 2016), it got a honorable mention at the International Prize Felifa-Fola, (Argentina 2016), it was selected as the best photography book of 2016 in Brazil, it was included in the show Fenomeno Fotolibro at the Contemporary Culture Center of Barcelona (Spain 2017), was included in the photobook exhibition of the Athens Photo Festival (Greece, 2017) and in the Photobook Fair of Lisbon (Portugal 2017).

His series have been published in specialized magazines such as VICE, GEO, GUP and others. His work has been also published in several photography books. His work has been showed in several festivals and collective exhibitions in Latin America, Europe and Asia, in addition to solo shows in Ecuador and Russia. Among his most important awards are the Photojournalism for Peace Prize of Ecuador (2017), the National Arts Prize of Ecuador (2015), honorable mentions in the contest Visura (2015, 2013, 2011) and he was a finalist in the Sony World Photography Awards (2015). He was a tutor at the 20 Photographers Camp Mexico.
 

Isadora Romero. Ecuador, 1987
Fotógrafa y videorealizadora ecuatoriana. Investigadora de la imagen y docente. Ha expuesto individual y colectivamente sus series “ Polvo de Estrellas” ;“Diarios de Dobleexposición”; “Un lugar en el Tiempo”; “Traducción”; “ Simbiosis” y “ Puño y Letra” en Ecuador y Argentina entre 2010 y 2017.
Entre sus distinciones destacan el haber ganado el Premio Fotoperiodismo por la Paz de Ecuador en 2017; ser la finalista del Inge Morath Award de Magnum Foundation en 2017, quedar seleccionada como finalista en el festival Cortona on the Move, Italia, con su serie Polvo de estrellas. Haber quedado seleccionada para el New York times portfolio review del mismo año. Ser finalista del concurso de fotolibros Felifa Futura en Buenos Aires a fines de 2016. Las versiones multimedia de sus proyectos “Noche Liquida” y “Polvo de Estrellas”  fueron seleccionadas para Slideluck Buenos Aires y Nápoles respectivamente y también en Santander Photo.
Fue seleccionada como tutora del campamento 20 fotógrafos México. Ha publicado en revistas y diarios especializados en Colombia, Ecuador, Argentina, Alemania, Francia, Italia y E.E.U.U. como VICE, Le Monde, entre otros. Sus series han formado parte de publicaciones de editorial RM México y Lens Culture. Miembro de la directiva de la Asociación de Fotógrafos Ecuatorianos, parte de la cuenta de instagram @everydayecuador de los Everydayprojects y de Woman Photograph.

Isadora Romero. Ecuador, 1987.
She is an Ecuadorian photographer and filmmaker, researcher of the image and teacher. She has exhibited individually and collectively her series "Stardust"; "Double Exposure Diaries"; "A Place in Time"; "Translation"; "Symbiosis" and "Handwritten" in Ecuador and Argentina between 2010 and 2017. Her awards include winning the Ecuadorian Photojournalism Award for Peace in 2017; she was the finalist of the Inge Morath Award of the Magnum Foundation in 2017, she was selected as a finalist at the Cortona on the Move festival, Italy, with her series “Stardust”. She was selected for the New York Portfolio Review the same year. She was also a finalist at the Felifa-Futura photo contest in Buenos Aires at the end of 2016. The multimedia versions of her projects "Liquid Night" and "Stardust" were screened at Slideluck Buenos Aires and Naples respectively, as well as in the Santander Photo Festival. She was selected as a tutor of the 20 Photographers Camp Mexico. She has published in specialized magazines in Colombia, Ecuador, Argentina, Germany, France, Italy and USA such as VICE, Le Monde, Topic Stories among others. Her series have been part of publications by RM Mexico and Lens Culture. She is a member of the board of the Ecuadorian Photographers’ Association, and takes part in the Instagram account @everydayecuador and in Woman Photograph.

Ecuador, 1985Es un fotógrafo que se mueve en la frontera entre lo documental y artístico.  En el 2014 terminó una Maestría en Artes en Fotografía Documental en la Universidad de las Artes de Londres. Es miembro del colectivo Runa Photos desde el 2012. En el 2016 publica su primer fotolibro “Al otro lado” con Editora Madalena de Sao Paulo, Brasil. Esta publicación fue seleccionada como uno de los mejores libros de autor del año por el festival Rencontres de la Photographie de Arles, Francia, obtuvo una mención de honor en el Premio Internacional Felifa-Fola Argentina 2016, fue elegido mejor libro de fotografía del 2016 de Brasil, fue incluido en la exhibición Fenómeno Fotolibro en el CCCB de Barcelona y fue incluido en la exhibición de fotolibros de Athens Photo Festival 2017.Su trabajo ha sido mostrado en varios festivales y exposiciones colectivas de Latinoamérica, Europa y Asia, además de haber sido expuesto en solitario en Rusia y Ecuador. Entre sus reconocimientos más importantes se encuentran haber ganado el Premio Fotoperiodismo Por La Paz (2017), el Premio Nacional de las Artes de Ecuador Nuevo Mariano Aguilera (2015), haber tenido menciones de honor en el concurso FotoVisura (2015, 2013 y 2011) y haber sido finalista en el concurso Sony World Photography Awards (2015).Misha Vallejo. Ecuador, 1985.He is a photographer that moves between documentary and art photography. In 2014 he finished an MA in Documentary Photography at the University of the Arts London. He is a member of the Runa Photos collective since 2012. In 2016 he published his first photobook “Al otro lado” with Brazilian publishing house Editora Madalena. This publication was selected as one of the best author books by the Rencontres de la Photographie Festival in Arles (France 2016), it got a honorable mention at the International Prize Felifa-Fola, (Argentina 2016), it was selected as the best photography book of 2016 in Brazil, it was included in the show Fenomeno Fotolibro at the Contemporary Culture Center of Barcelona (Spain 2017), was included in the photobook exhibition of the Athens Photo Festival (Greece, 2017) and in the Photobook Fair of Lisbon (Portugal 2017).His series have been published in specialized magazines such as VICE, GEO, GUP and others. His work has been also published in several photography books. His work has been showed in several festivals and collective exhibitions in Latin America, Europe and Asia, in addition to solo shows in Ecuador and Russia. Among his most important awards are the Photojournalism for Peace Prize of Ecuador (2017), the National Arts Prize of Ecuador (2015), honorable mentions in the contest Visura (2015, 2013, 2011) and he was a finalist in the Sony World Photography Awards (2015). He was a tutor at the 20 Photographers Camp Mexico. Isadora Romero. Ecuador, 1987Fotógrafa y videorealizadora ecuatoriana. Investigadora de la imagen y docente. Ha expuesto individual y colectivamente sus series “ Polvo de Estrellas” ;“Diarios de Dobleexposición”; “Un lugar en el Tiempo”; “Traducción”; “ Simbiosis” y “ Puño y Letra” en Ecuador y Argentina entre 2010 y 2017.Entre sus distinciones destacan el haber ganado el Premio Fotoperiodismo por la Paz de Ecuador en 2017; ser la finalista del Inge Morath Award de Magnum Foundation en 2017, quedar seleccionada como finalista en el festival Cortona on the Move, Italia, con su serie Polvo de estrellas. Haber quedado seleccionada para el New York times portfolio review del mismo año. Ser finalista del concurso de fotolibros Felifa Futura en Buenos Aires a fines de 2016. Las versiones multimedia de sus proyectos “Noche Liquida” y “Polvo de Estrellas”  fueron seleccionadas para Slideluck Buenos Aires y Nápoles respectivamente y también en Santander Photo.Fue seleccionada como tutora del campamento 20 fotógrafos México. Ha publicado en revistas y diarios especializados en Colombia, Ecuador, Argentina, Alemania, Francia, Italia y E.E.U.U. como VICE, Le Monde, entre otros. Sus series han formado parte de publicaciones de editorial RM México y Lens Culture. Miembro de la directiva de la Asociación de Fotógrafos Ecuatorianos, parte de la cuenta de instagram @everydayecuador de los Everydayprojects y de Woman Photograph.Isadora Romero. Ecuador, 1987.She is an Ecuadorian photographer and filmmaker, researcher of the image and teacher. She has exhibited individually and collectively her series "Stardust"; "Double Exposure Diaries"; "A Place in Time"; "Translation"; "Symbiosis" and "Handwritten" in Ecuador and Argentina between 2010 and 2017. Her awards include winning the Ecuadorian Photojournalism Award for Peace in 2017; she was the finalist of the Inge Morath Award of the Magnum Foundation in 2017, she was selected as a finalist at the Cortona on the Move festival, Italy, with her series “Stardust”. She was selected for the New York Portfolio Review the same year. She was also a finalist at the Felifa-Futura photo contest in Buenos Aires at the end of 2016. The multimedia versions of her projects "Liquid Night" and "Stardust" were screened at Slideluck Buenos Aires and Naples respectively, as well as in the Santander Photo Festival. She was selected as a tutor of the 20 Photographers Camp Mexico. She has published in specialized magazines in Colombia, Ecuador, Argentina, Germany, France, Italy and USA such as VICE, Le Monde, Topic Stories among others. Her series have been part of publications by RM Mexico and Lens Culture. She is a member of the board of the Ecuadorian Photographers’ Association, and takes part in the Instagram account @everydayecuador and in Woman Photograph.

story:
For the past 13 years, I have been producing projects involving themes of vulnerability, longing, and impulsive behavior. For the past two years, I have developed a few body of works that physically penetrate the photographic print while the image penetrates the psychology of the viewer. CRUSH is a series that uses large crumpled and cut photographs in sculptural collages. POLISHED turns the camera's power on to the photographer where he becomes the vulnerable naked model.

In my latest project, FLASH, I address the tough questions our society is currently facing with regards to gender identification.  The current debate we are seeing on gender issues now, provides an opportunity to expand beyond current widely accepted norms.  I am excited to use this project to question what is considered acceptable and offer a forum to break through social boundaries.

The crucial part of this project is the ‘edit’ that will give the viewer a new appearance of taboo subjects through direct relationships between objects, places, and bodies in the images and the rearrangement of photographer and model roles. 

This idea is a positive contribution to the idea that oppressive identification of others can be undone by rearranging the logic of traditional power relationships involving gender.  Personal decision making about gender is left with the individual and not a governing institution.  In other words, the power over one's appearance rests with the individual rather than the perceiver or onlooker.  By contributing and promoting this work, supporters will be helping to redistribute power among the genders.

For this project, I’m utilizing a Polaroid instant camera and flash to investigate instant gratification while rearranging the logic of the relationship between model and photographer. Models self-select through casting calls I create on sites like Model Mayhem to generate interest in the project.  The paid models in the book have chosen to participate in this project because it connects with their creative work too.  The collection of images will have models, objects and places as well as images of myself in situations similar to that of the model.  This is one way I put myself in the model’s shoes.  

I think the best way to present this idea is with a book.  I envision a small book that will fit well and feel good in your hands.  The dimensions will be slightly larger than a print (4.25" x 3.5").  I plan on a small edition run first for exhibition then put the book in wider circulation. This will be a learning process for me as this is the first book I have tried to publish.  Any recommendations on book publishing is welcomed!

I will be shooting for the book in Dallas, TX as well as in Berlin Germany.  I have been accepted into a two-month artist residency at the Institut für Alles Mögliche (Institute for All Things Possible) in Berlin for November and December 2017.  This online campaign will cover the project expenses for FLASH such as book publishing, purchase of film from the Impossible Project, rent (for the artist residency) and travel expenses to Berlin Germany.

If you feel this is a positive project that you would like to support but cannot contribute financially.  Feel free to post this campaign on your social media pages especially Facebook, Google + and Instagram.  I will be happy to assist in any promotions you are willing to do. 

With Gratitude, 

Tim Best

story:
Renowned Artist, H.C.Porter lives part-time in Annapolis, MD, when she does not reside in Mississippi. For her, it is important to bring this exhibit to Blues music fans in the Greater Baltimore-Washington D.C. area now that it has gained fame in different areas of Mississippi.

Maryland Hall—with its 725-seat theatre and 3 professional galleries—is the perfect fit for this multi-sensory exhibition and performance opportunity. 

      

H.C. Porter, Mickey Rogers, (left) Fine Art Photograph (right) Mixed Media  

 H.C. Porter, a Jackson, Mississippi, native, is an internationally-known painter, print-maker and photographer with a signature gallery in historic downtown Vicksburg, Mississippi. Her artwork is in private and corporate collections around the globe and has been featured in numerous museum exhibitions for the past 30 years. Most recently, the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture in Washington, D.C., added one of Porter’s pieces to their collection. In 2015, her Backyards and Beyond painting series became a permanent exhibition in the Ground Zero Hurricane Museum in Waveland, MS. Her work is featured on CD covers, including one featuring the voices of Maya Angelou, Patti LaBelle and Chaka Khan. Porter’s work is also featured on the cover of Beyond Katrina, a book by U.S. Poet Laureate Natasha Trethewey. Her work hangs in the Mississippi Senate offices in Washington, D.C., and is in the collection of former Mississippi Gov. Haley Barbour and Marsha Barbour. In 2009, Porter received the Mississippi Institute for Arts and Letters Visual Arts Award and was included in the 2011 Mississippi Invitational at the Mississippi Museum of Art. She has been the recipient of a Visual Artistic Fellowship from the Mississippi Arts Commission.

  

H.C. Porter at Blues @ Home Exhibition

Funders will contribute to the packing, shipping, and travel of the exhibition as well as installation and marketing costs. Supporters can also help support an unforgettable live performance by some of the living legends showcased in one of Maryland Hall's performance spaces. 

Maryland Hall is seeking $10,000 for the multi-sensory exhibition and live music to travel to Maryland Hall.

Costs include:

Shipping and rental fees, installation costs, full artwork insurance, audio tour with wands (hear the stories of the legends through recorded oral histories on hand-held audio devices), publicity packet with templates, thirty title text panels and four informative text panels.

hear the stories of the legends through recorded oral histories

Additional costs include travel and hotel accommodations for musicians to play a  live music event.

      

H.C. Porter's Blues @ Home, B B King Museum, Indianola, photographs by Melani Thortis

 

Dedicated to Art for All, Maryland Hall for the Creative Arts is the community’s arts center, providing lifelong, accessible  engagement in the arts.

Serving 100,000 people each year, Maryland Hall educates, enriches and enhances lives through performances, exhibitions, education classes and outreach programs. 

Maryland Hall for the Creative Arts, Photograph by Alison Harbaugh

 

If you cannot contribute monetarily please help us by sharing this campaign

Please share this and our other accounts to as many friends and family as possible. We want to reach a large audience and we would love your help!

  • Facebook - Maryland Hall for the Creative Arts
  • Instagram - @marylandhall
  • Twitter - @marylandhall
  • Facebook: H.C. Porter Gallery (There’s also a Blues at Home page)​
  • Instagram: hcportergallery (business) or hcporter1 (personal)
  • Twitter: @HCPorter2

  

   

       

H.C. Porter's Blues @ Home | B.B. King Museum, Indianola, Photographs by Melani Thortis
